The Myxozoa are a group of microscopic parasites that are the most diverse group of parasitic animals. They are also the most enigmatic, with a long-standing debate about their evolutionary origin. Here, we provide the first genomic and transcriptomic data for two species of myxozoans, which allowed us to compare the genome and transcriptome of a parasitic cnidarian to that of a parasitic noncnidarian. Our results show that the myxozoan body plan is reduced to the bare minimum, with a genome size that is one of the smallest among animals. This reduction is accompanied by a reduction in gene content and expression of genes involved in development and cell–cell communication. Our results provide insights into the extreme evolutionary transition from a free-living cnidarian to a parasitic cnidarian. (Show more)

The proton channel Hv1 is involved in many physiological processes, such as pH homeostasis and the innate immune response. Zn2+ is an important physiological inhibitor of Hv1. In this study, we use the voltage clamp fluorometry technique to identify the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of Hv1. We find that Zn2+ binds to both the activated closed and resting closed states of the Hv1 channel, thereby inhibiting both voltage sensor motion and gate opening. These effects are similar in monomeric and dimeric Hv1 channels, suggesting that the Zn2+-binding sites are localized within each subunit of the Hv1 dimer. We propose that Zn2+ binding has two major effects on Hv1: (i) at low concentrations, Zn2+ binds to one site and prevents the opening conformational change of the pore of Hv1, thereby inhibiting proton conduction; and (ii) at high concentrations, Zn2+, in addition, binds to a second site and inhibits the outward movement of the voltage sensor of Hv1. Elucidating the molecular mechanism of how Zn2+ inhibits Hv1 will further our understanding of Hv1 function and might provide valuable information for future drug development for Hv1 channels.

Climate change will affect the global food supply, but the magnitude of the impact is uncertain. We show that, absent changes in temperature variability or breeding gains in heat tolerance, the coefficient of variation of maize yields will increase to values much larger than present-day values, and the probability of simultaneous production losses greater than 10% in any given year will increase. This instability in global grain trade and international grain prices will affect especially the ∼800 million people living in extreme poverty who are most vulnerable to food price spikes. We also show that, under 2 °C of global warming, the optimum growing temperature will be exceeded in most of the world’s major maize-producing countries, and that the optimum growing temperature will be exceeded in all of them under 4 °C of global warming. These results underscore the urgency of investments in breeding for heat tolerance. (Abridged)

The extent to which large mammalian herbivores partition food resources is largely unknown because of the difficulty of quantifying diet composition at the species level. We used DNA metabarcoding to quantify diet breadth, composition, and overlap for seven abundant large mammal species in semiarid African savanna. We found that the extent of dietary overlap was greater between species that were similar in body size and proportional grass consumption than within either grass- or browse-dominated guilds. Dietary overlap was also greater between species that were similar in body size and proportional grass consumption than between species that were similar in body size and proportional browse consumption. These results suggest that coarse trophic categorizations may generate misleading conclusions about competition and coexistence in large mammal assemblages, and that large mammal diversity may be more tightly linked to plant diversity than is currently recognized. This may have important implications for the management of large mammal populations and the conservation of savanna ecosystems. (Show more)

We conducted a survey of more than 5,800 small businesses in the United States to understand the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on their operations. We find that many businesses have already laid off employees and closed their doors. Many businesses are financially fragile, with only about 2 wk of cash on hand. Finally, many businesses expect the crisis to last for many months.

Plastic debris is one of the most widespread forms of marine pollution. However, the global load of plastic on the open ocean surface is still unknown. We show that the global load of plastic on the open ocean surface is far less than expected, mostly due to size-selective sinks. Our results suggest that the missing plastic debris is likely to be transported to the ocean interior, where it may be trapped in the deep ocean.

The origin of the solar system is one of the most important questions in science. The solar system is thought to have formed from the gravitational collapse of a molecular cloud. However, the formation of the solar system is not yet fully understood. In this study, we determined the ages of presolar silicon carbide grains extracted from the Murchison CM2 meteorite. The ages of the grains range from 3.9 Ma to ∼3 Ga. The grains with ages of <300 Ma are shorter than theoretical estimates for large grains. This suggests that the grains condensed in outflows of asymptotic giant branch stars <4.9 Ga ago that possibly formed during an episode of enhanced star formation ∼7 Ga ago. The grains with ages >1 Ga suggest that the bulk of their cosmogenic nuclides were acquired in the interstellar medium. This indicates that the solar system formed from the gravitational collapse of a molecular cloud. However, the formation of the solar system is not yet fully understood. This study provides new insights into the formation of the solar system. (Abridged)

Multiple system atrophy (MSA) is a sporadic neurodegenerative disorder that affects the autonomic nervous system and the basal ganglia. The disease is fatal within a few years after disease onset, and there is no treatment available to slow down the disease process. In this study, we show that the caspase-1 inhibitor VX-765, which was well tolerated in a 6 wk-long phase II trial in patients with epilepsy, is a promising candidate to achieve disease modification in synucleinopathies by limiting α-syn accumulation.

The endothelium is the lining of the blood vessels. It is responsible for controlling the exchange of oxygen, nutrients, and waste products between the blood and the tissues. It also controls the contractility of the blood vessels, hemostasis, and inflammation. The endothelium is composed of a single layer of cells that are connected by a network of connections. The network is responsible for the communication between the cells. The network is very complex and is composed of thousands of cells. We have developed a method to measure the communication between the cells. The results show that the network is highly connected and has a small-world configuration. This configuration is very effective for the communication between the cells.

The COVID-19 pandemic has been a major public health crisis, and the data needs are enormous. We have developed a data infrastructure, the COVIDcast API, that provides open access to a wide range of data on the pandemic, including many auxiliary signals that are not typically available. These data are available at a fine geographic resolution and are updated daily. The data are available in a common format through the API and accompanying R and Python software packages. This infrastructure is intended to empower researchers and policy makers to track the pandemic and its impact, and to empower the public to make informed decisions. We hope that this infrastructure will be useful to the research community and the public.

Potassium channels are the most abundant ion channels in the human body. They are involved in a wide variety of physiological processes, such as the control of heart rate and blood pressure, the transmission of nerve impulses, and the regulation of muscle contraction. Inactivation of these channels is crucial for the control of their function. We have identified a key residue that is involved in the allosteric communication between the selectivity filter and the activation gate of potassium channels. This allosteric communication is crucial for the control of the selectivity filter’s conformation and, consequently, for the control of the channel’s function.

One of the most important aspects of the microbiome is the diversity of the microorganisms that inhabit the gut. The diversity of the microbiome is thought to be important for the health of the host. Social dominance is a fundamental aspect of social groups, yet the role of personality traits in the establishment of social hierarchy is largely unknown. Here we show that anxiety, a personality trait that is associated with a low probability to become dominant, is reflected in reduced mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens. We further demonstrate that the low probability to become dominant in high-anxious animals is due to a reduced probability to become subordinate in low-anxious animals. Our findings indicate that mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens is crucial for social hierarchy establishment and point to mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens as a potential marker and avenue of treatment for anxiety-related social disorders. This work provides a mechanistic understanding of the role of personality traits in social dominance and may lead to the development of new therapeutic approaches for anxiety-related social disorders. The design of mechanical structures with desired responses is a fundamental problem in the field of mechanical engineering. However, the design space is restricted by the material properties and the structural patterns are limited by the designer’s experience. Here, we propose a free-form inverse design approach to synthesize multiple hyperelastic materials into composite structures to precisely achieve arbitrary and extreme prescribed responses under large deformations. The synthesized structures exhibit organic shapes and motions with irregular distributions of material phases. Within the structures, different materials play distinct roles yet seamlessly collaborate through sophisticated deformation mechanisms to produce the target behaviors. The proposed synthesis, multimaterial fabrication, and heteroassembly strategy can be utilized to design function-oriented and situation-specific mechanical devices for a wide range of applications. This work provides a new paradigm for the design of mechanical structures with desired responses. It is expected to inspire the design of mechanical systems with complex behaviors in the future.

The hemoglobin system is a key component of the oxygen transport system in the human body. The hemoglobin system is also a target of the let-7 microRNA pathway. Here we show that the insulin-like growth factor 2 mRNA-binding protein 1 (IGF2BP1) is a downstream element of the let-7 pathway in erythroid cells. We demonstrate that IGF2BP1 is developmentally down-regulated in fetal liver and that overexpression of IGF2BP1 in adult erythroid cells results in a reversal of the adult hemoglobin expression pattern toward a more fetal-like pattern. This study provides a mechanism for chronoregulation of the hemoglobin system in humans. This mechanism may be relevant to the hemoglobinopathies and to the development of hemoglobin therapies. Cancer is the number one cause of death worldwide. Despite the tremendous advances in cancer treatment, the survival rate of patients with advanced cancer remains low. In this study, we found that the activation of the PI3K-AKT-mTOR signaling pathway confers resistance to ferroptosis, a form of regulated necrosis that is a promising therapy for cancer. We also found that the activation of the PI3K-AKT-mTOR pathway protects cancer cells from oxidative stress and ferroptotic death through sterol regulatory element-binding protein 1/stearoyl-CoA desaturase-1-mediated lipogenesis, and that combination of mTORC1 inhibition with ferroptosis induction shows therapeutic promise in preclinical models. Our findings provide a new strategy for cancer treatment. (Show more)

Hypertension is the leading cause of heart failure. The treatment of hypertension is the cornerstone of cardiovascular disease prevention. The most widely used drugs for treating hypertension are the L-type Ca2+ channel blockers (LCCBs). However, the use of LCCBs is associated with the development of heart failure. Here, we show that LCCBs activate Ca2+ signaling in vascular smooth muscle cells (VSMCs) and promote vascular remodeling. Our findings provide a rationale for the use of LCCBs in the elderly or patients with advanced hypertension and/or onset of cardiovascular remodeling.

The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy that changed the way forests were managed in the Pacific Northwest. We show that the NWFP halted the decline of bird populations in the Pacific Northwest, but that the policy has not yet been successful in reversing the decline of older-forest–associated bird populations. We also show that the NWFP has not been successful in halting the decline of early-seral bird populations. The NWFP is now 25 years old, and it is time to assess its success.

Antibiotic resistance is a major threat to global health. The development of new antibiotics is a major challenge for the scientific community. In this work, we present a rational design approach to develop new antibiotics. The approach is based on the prediction of the physicochemical properties of the compounds, which are then tested in vitro and in vivo. The best compounds are then tested for their activity against antibiotic-resistant pathogens. The results show that the best compounds designed by us are active against antibiotic-resistant pathogens, especially when combined with the membrane-weakening drug colistin. The approach presented here can be used to develop new antibiotics against other antibiotic-resistant pathogens. (Show more)

The Lake Malawi cichlid fish species flock is one of the most diverse and iconic groups of fishes on Earth. Here we show that the species flock is also one of the most dynamic, with the habitat of the lake changing dramatically over the last 1.3 My. We show that the species flock evolved in a changing environment, with the habitat of the lake responding to climate change and the evolution of the species flock being driven by the changing environment.

The use of electronic devices for reading and entertainment has become ubiquitous in the past 50 y. However, the impact of these devices on sleep is unknown. Here we show that reading an electronic book on a light-emitting device (LE-eBook) suppresses melatonin, reduces the timing of the circadian clock, and reduces alertness the following morning. These effects are similar to those of reading a printed book, but the LE-eBook has the added disadvantage of phase-delaying the circadian clock and suppressing melatonin. This may have important implications for health, safety, and performance.

The Younger Dryas cooling is a well-known event that has been attributed to a bolide impact. However, the exact nature of the impactor is still debated. In this paper, we show that the osmium isotopic composition of the Younger Dryas sediments is consistent with a terrestrial impact. The osmium isotopic composition of the spherules from the same site suggests that the impactor was a meteorite that originated in the Grenville Province of northeastern North America.

The role of CTLA-4 in the immune system is controversial, and its specific function in the development of autoimmunity is unknown. Here, we show that CTLA-4 is essential for the development of autoimmunity, and that its function is not limited to the regulation of T cell responses. We found that CTLA-4 is required for the development of autoimmunity in both the thymus and periphery. Moreover, we found that CTLA-4 is required for the development of autoimmunity in both the thymus and periphery.

Beetles are arguably the most speciose group of animals, but the evolutionary history of beetles, including the impacts of plant feeding on beetle diversification, remain poorly understood. We reconstructed the evolutionary history of beetles, including the origins of plant feeding, using a comprehensive dataset of genes encoding enzymes that digest plant cell walls. Our results show that the evolution of beetles was shaped by multiple factors, including low extinction rates over a long evolutionary history, codiversification with angiosperms, and adaptive radiations of specialized herbivorous beetles following convergent horizontal transfers of microbial genes encoding enzymes that digest plant cell walls. These results provide insights into the evolution of the most speciose group of animals. (Show more)

We show that the extent to which larger populations enhance cumulative cultural evolution (CCE) is contentious. We show that, in a large-scale experiment, the CCE of technology (paper planes and their flight distances) is not enhanced by larger populations. We also show that the CCE of technology is not enhanced by larger populations in a specific set of conditions. We discuss the implications of these findings for the evolution of technology and culture.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia. The strongest genetic risk factor for AD is the APOE ε4 allele. APOE is a lipid-binding protein that is highly expressed in the brain. Here, we report a novel role for APOE in regulating the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes. We also found that the presence of APOE4 increases the accumulation of a complement component in the brain, which may contribute to the increased vulnerability of synapses to complement-mediated neurodegeneration. These studies reveal a novel allele-dependent role for APOE in regulating the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes. They also suggest the hypothesis that AD susceptibility of APOE4 may originate in part from defective phagocytic capacity of astrocytes which accelerates the rate of accumulation of senescent synapses, enhancing synaptic vulnerability to classical-complement-cascade mediated neurodegeneration.

The Earth's inner core is a solid core that is separated from the mantle by a sharp boundary. It is one of the most mysterious parts of the Earth. The inner core is thought to have formed by the solidification of molten iron. However, the nucleation mechanism of the inner core is still a mystery. We show that the nucleation of the inner core is likely to be a two-step process, which is different from the solidification of the outer core. This mechanism reduces the required undercooling of iron nucleation, which provides a key factor in solving the inner core nucleation paradox.

Marijuana is the most widely used illicit drug in the United States. Although the effects of marijuana on the brain are well known, the effects of chronic marijuana use on the brain are not. Here, we show that chronic marijuana use is associated with reduced reactivity of the brain to methylphenidate, a drug that elevates extracellular dopamine (DA) levels in the brain. This reduced reactivity is associated with increased stress reactivity and irritability, and with increased addiction severity and craving.

Language is the defining cognitive ability of the human species. Despite its importance, the human brain’s mechanisms for comprehending language are poorly understood. Here, we use a powerful new class of artificial neural networks, “transformers,” to model brain responses to language processing in humans. We find that these models capture nearly 100% of the neural variance in response to sentences, generalize across datasets, and are strongly correlated with behavioral performance. This provides computational evidence that predictive processing fundamentally shapes the language comprehension mechanisms in the human brain. Our results have implications for understanding the neural and computational mechanisms of language processing, as well as for the development of artificial intelligence.

Deep learning (DL) has had unprecedented success in many areas of science and engineering. However, it is still unclear whether DL is a special case of a more general class of problems, or whether it is fundamentally different. In this paper, we show that there are problems in scientific computing where one can prove the existence of stable neural networks (NNs) with great approximation qualities. However, there does not exist any algorithm, even randomized, that can train (or compute) such a NN. This implies a classification theory describing conditions under which (stable) NNs with a given accuracy can be computed by an algorithm. We introduce fast iterative restarted networks (FIRENETs), which we both prove and numerically verify are stable. Moreover, we prove that only O(|log (ϵ)|) layers are needed for an ϵ-accurate solution to the inverse problem. Our results provide a theoretical foundation for the use of DL in scientific computing.

The COVID-19 pandemic is a global tragedy. It is also a textbook example of the failure of social distancing. The failure is not due to people’s inability to understand exponential growth. It is due to the failure of a classic psychological experiment published 45 years ago.

Leprosy is a disease that has been with us for thousands of years. It is caused by two bacteria, Mycobacterium leprae, which infects the peripheral nerves, and Mycobacterium lepromatosis, which causes a diffuse form of the disease. Here we report the genome sequence of M. lepromatosis, which is the first genome sequence of a leprosy bacterium. We also show that M. lepromatosis is more closely related to the leprosy bacterium than to other mycobacteria.

Entanglement and entropy are key concepts in quantum mechanics. They are the basis of the quantum theory of information, and they are also the key ingredients of thermodynamics. In this work, we show that the entanglement dynamics is captured by a statistical ensemble with a nonzero thermodynamic entropy, which is the accumulated entanglement. This result is valid for both interacting and noninteracting systems, and it is exact in the quasiparticle picture of the entanglement dynamics.

The COVID-19 pandemic is a global health emergency that has affected millions of people worldwide. The development of a vaccine is the only way to control the pandemic. Here, we describe a vaccine candidate, COVI-VAC, that is currently in clinical development. The vaccine is based on a temperature-sensitive mutant of SARS-CoV-2, which is attenuated in vitro and in vivo. The vaccine is easy to manufacture, can be stored at room temperature, and is expected to be highly immunogenic. The vaccine is expected to be effective in mass vaccination programs. Thus, COVI-VAC is a promising vaccine candidate for the COVID-19 pandemic. (Show more)

The Second Pandemic of plague (14–19th centuries) led to high mortality and recurrent epidemics for hundreds of years. The vector of plague during this period is unknown. Here, we use a compartmental model to investigate the role of human ectoparasites, such as fleas and lice, as vectors. We find that the model fits mortality curves from nine outbreaks in Europe better than models for rodent or pneumonic transmission. Our results support that human ectoparasites were primary vectors for plague during the Second Pandemic, including the Black Death (1346–1353), ultimately challenging the assumption that plague in Europe was predominantly spread by rats. This work provides a better understanding of the history of plague in Europe and may help to prevent future outbreaks.

The evolution of brain size is a key topic in the study of animal cognition. However, it is not the only factor that determines the cognitive capacity of an animal. In this study, we show that the evolution of brain size is not the only factor that determines the cognitive capacity of an animal. We show that the evolution of the number of neurons in the brain is also important.

The molecular chaperone TRAP1 is found predominantly in mitochondria. It is broadly considered to be an anticancer target. However, current inhibitors cannot distinguish between TRAP1 and HSP90, the target of many anticancer drugs. We have used TRAP1-null cells and transient TRAP1 silencing/overexpression to show that TRAP1 regulates a metabolic switch between oxidative phosphorylation and aerobic glycolysis in immortalized mouse fibroblasts and in human tumor cells. TRAP1-deficiency promotes an increase in mitochondrial respiration and fatty acid oxidation, and in cellular accumulation of tricarboxylic acid cycle intermediates, ATP and reactive oxygen species. At the same time, glucose metabolism is suppressed. TRAP1-deficient cells also display strikingly enhanced invasiveness. TRAP1 interaction with and regulation of mitochondrial c-Src provide a mechanistic basis for these phenotypes. Taken together with the observation that TRAP1 expression is inversely correlated with tumor grade in several cancers, these data suggest that, in some settings, this mitochondrial molecular chaperone may act as a tumor suppressor. This work may lead to the development of new therapies for cancer and other diseases. (Show more)

Actin depolymerizing factor (ADF) is a protein that is involved in the disassembly of actin filaments. It does so by binding to the barbed end of the filament and severing it. However, the mechanism by which ADF/cofilin severes actin filaments is not known. Here, we use single-molecule, single-filament, and filament network techniques to study the action of ADF/cofilin in different mechanical situations. We find that ADF/cofilin binds to the barbed end of the filament and that this binding is enhanced by local curvature. Surprisingly, we find that tension has no effect on ADF/cofilin binding, but that tension enhances severing. We propose that the enhanced severing is due to the ADF/cofilin-induced filament twist. This mechanochemical mechanism is critical to boost ADF/cofilin’s ability to sever highly connected filament networks in cells. We believe that our findings will be of interest to the broader scientific community.

Fructose, a common sweetener, is widely used in the food industry. However, the effects of fructose on brain and behavior have not been well studied. In this study, we show that ingestion of fructose relative to glucose results in greater activation of brain regions involved in attention and reward processing and may promote feeding behavior. These findings have implications for understanding the effects of fructose on brain and behavior.

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across the island, from the north to the south, from the east to the west. We found that the Malagasy population is a mixture of Bantu and Austronesian populations, with a limited contribution from Europe and the Middle East. The distribution of African and Asian ancestry across the island reveals that the admixture was sex biased and happened heterogeneously across Madagascar, suggesting independent colonization of Madagascar from Africa and Asia rather than settlement by an already admixed population. In addition, a few centuries is sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. This study provides a comprehensive view of the genomic diversity of Madagascar. It is a unique resource for the scientific community. It will be used to study the human history of Madagascar and the Indian Ocean. It will also be used to study the human history of Africa and Southeast Asia. (Show more)

We show that people’s emotions are influenced by the emotions of others on Facebook. This is a form of emotional contagion, which has been shown in laboratory experiments, but has not been observed in the real world. Our results suggest that people are influenced by the emotions of others, even when they are not interacting with them in person. This work also suggests that, in contrast to prevailing assumptions, in-person interaction and nonverbal cues are not strictly necessary for emotional contagion, and that the observation of others’ positive experiences constitutes a positive experience for people. Our findings have implications for our understanding of the spread of emotions in society.

The vast majority of RNA in the cell is not protein-coding, and noncoding RNAs have a wide range of functions. One of the most common modifications in coding regions of messenger RNAs (mRNAs) is pseudouridine (Ψ), which is present in 10–20% of uridine nucleotides. We show that the presence of Ψ in an mRNA codon can impede the activation of the elongation factor EF-Tu and the addition of amino acids to the growing peptide chain. We also find that the presence of Ψ can promote the synthesis of multiple peptide products from a single mRNA sequence in the cell. These findings suggest that the presence of Ψ in mRNAs can have a modest impact on protein synthesis. Our work also provides insights into the structure of the 70S ribosome and the mechanism of the EF-Tu GTPase. (Show more)

This study shows that the feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities is associated with a wide range of positive outcomes, including better health and social relationships. This finding has implications for the design of interventions to promote healthy aging.

The evolution of larger body sizes in aquatic mammals is a key feature of the evolution of vertebrates into the water. We show that the evolution of an aquatic lifestyle is driving three of the four extant aquatic mammal clades toward a size attractor at ∼500 kg. The existence of this body size attractor and the relatively rapid selection toward, and limited deviation from, this attractor rule out most hypothesized drivers of size increase. Rather than being released from size pressures, water-dwelling mammals are driven and confined to larger body sizes by the strict energetic demands of the aquatic medium. Our results provide a new perspective on the evolution of body size in vertebrates.

Rhinovirus is the most common cause of the common cold. The temperature dependence of rhinovirus replication has been attributed to a reduced antiviral defense response of infected cells at cool temperature. Here, we show that mouse airway cells infected with mouse-adapted rhinovirus exhibit a striking enrichment in expression of antiviral defense response genes at 37 °C relative to 33 °C. This correlates with higher expression levels of type I and type III IFN genes and ISGs at 37 °C. Temperature-dependent IFN induction in response to rhinovirus is dependent on the MAVS protein, a key signaling adaptor of the RIG-I–like receptors (RLRs). Stimulation of primary airway cells with the synthetic RLR ligand poly I:C leads to greater IFN induction at 37 °C relative to 33 °C at early time points poststimulation and to a sustained increase in the induction of ISGs at 37 °C relative to 33 °C. The type IV pili of bacteria are major surface adhesins that are involved in a wide range of biological processes, including biofilm formation and pathogenicity. Here we show that the type IV pili of P. aeruginosa are also used as a sensor to detect the mechanical activity of the pili, and that this mechanochemical process is used to regulate the expression of genes involved in virulence. This mechanochemical process is used by P. aeruginosa to regulate its surface-associated virulence, and may be a general mechanism used by bacteria to sense the mechanical activity of their pili.

The global use of pesticides in agriculture is increasing, and the use of insecticides in particular is associated with a high risk for surface water. However, the extent of this risk is unknown because of a lack of comprehensive quantitative analysis. We provide a comprehensive metaanalysis of the global use of insecticides in agriculture and the occurrence of these chemicals in surface water. We show that the use of insecticides is widespread, and that the risk for surface water is high. This study provides a comprehensive picture of the global use of insecticides in agriculture and the occurrence of these chemicals in surface water. It is a first step toward the development of effective strategies for the reduction of the risk of insecticide contamination of surface water.

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a profound impact on human society, and the SARS-CoV-2 virus has spread to many animal species, including deer. Here, we report the detection of SARS-CoV-2 in free-living deer, and the discovery of multiple human and deer lineages. Our findings have important implications for the long-term persistence of the pandemic. We highlight the need for a robust and proactive “One Health” approach to obtain enhanced understanding of the ecology, molecular evolution, and dissemination of SARS-CoV-2. Our study also demonstrates the importance of a comprehensive sampling strategy, which is critical for the detection of emerging pathogens in free-living animals. (Show more)

The proliferation of large dams in the developing world is a global problem that is affecting the lives of millions of people. This paper examines the causes of this problem, the impacts of the dams, and the solutions that are needed. We also propose a new approach to the development of renewable energy that is more sustainable and equitable.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia, and the most prevalent form of dementia in the United States. The disease is characterized by the accumulation of the amyloid-β (Aβ) peptide and the neurofibrillary tangles (NFTs) of the microtubule-associated protein tau. The exact causes of AD are unknown, but it is thought to be a combination of genetic and environmental factors. In this study, we show that soluble Aβ is the primary cause of inflammation in the brain, and that this inflammation is unique to neurons.

The domestic chicken is one of the most widespread domesticated species in the world. However, the earliest evidence for its economic exploitation is still missing. Here we present the results of a comprehensive survey of the chicken in the archaeological record. We show that the earliest evidence for economic exploitation of chickens dates to the Hellenistic period in the Southern Levant. This is a crucial step in the adoption of this species in European husbandry some 100 y later.

We have developed a method that allows us to study the folding of a large protein at high structural resolution. We have used this method to study the folding of maltose binding protein. We find that the folding of maltose binding protein is a multistep process. The folding intermediates are native-like and are formed in a fast step and a slow step. The slow step is essential for folding.

Dinucleoside tetraphosphates (Np4) are alarmones that accumulate in response to stress. In bacteria, Np4 decapping is mediated by ApaH, which is inactivated by stress conditions that enable Np4 accumulation. Here, we show that, in the presence of stress, the pyrophosphohydrolase RppH, which is involved in the degradation of 5′ ends of RNA, becomes the predominant decapping enzyme. We show that RppH prefers Np4-capped RNAs as substrates, and that the Np4 cap is required for the activity of RppH. We also show that RppH decapsulates Np4-capped RNAs by a mechanism distinct from the one it uses to decapsulate other 5′ ends. This study provides insights into the role of Np4 in the stress response and the mechanisms by which bacteria adapt to stress. (Show more)

Sepsis is a major cause of mortality, and the development of new therapies is urgently needed. We have shown that arginine, a key amino acid, is essential for the function of T cells, and that its deficiency is associated with the development of sepsis-induced immunosuppression. We have also shown that citrulline, the metabolic isomer of arginine, is a potent inducer of arginine levels in the blood and that it is able to restore T cell function in sepsis. This study provides evidence for developing citrulline-based clinical studies in sepsis. This work also provides a rationale for the development of new therapies for sepsis. (Show more)

The biomass of all living organisms on Earth is a key parameter for understanding the structure and dynamics of the biosphere. However, a global, quantitative view of how the biomass of different taxa compare with one another is still lacking. Here, we assemble the overall biomass composition of the biosphere, establishing a census of the ≈550 Gt C of biomass distributed among all of the kingdoms of life. We find that the kingdoms of life concentrate at different locations on the planet; plants (≈450 Gt C, the dominant kingdom) are primarily terrestrial, whereas animals (≈2 Gt C) are mainly marine, and bacteria (≈70 Gt C) and archaea (≈7 Gt C) are predominantly located in deep subsurface environments. We also show that the global marine biomass pyramid contains more consumers than producers, thus increasing the scope of previous observations on inverse food pyramids. Finally, we highlight that the mass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined and report the historical impact of humanity on the global biomass of prominent taxa, including mammals, fish, and plants. Our results provide a global view of the biomass of the biosphere and its distribution among the kingdoms

Self-organized criticality (SOC) is a phenomenon in which a system, when perturbed, returns to a state of criticality, in which it is neither too slow nor too fast, but rather at a natural rate. SOC is observed in nature, in the behavior of earthquakes, avalanches, and so forth. In this paper, we report on our discovery of a model of SOC. Our model is continuous, in contrast to all known models of SOC, and is a certain scaling limit of the sandpile model, the first and archetypical model of SOC. We describe how our model is related to pattern formation and proportional growth phenomena and discuss the dichotomy between continuous and discrete models in several contexts. Our aim in this context is to present an idealized tropical toy model (cf. Turing reaction-diffusion model), requiring further investigation.

Diamond is a unique material with a wide range of applications in electronics, photonics, and quantum technologies. It is a promising material for quantum computing, but its electronic properties are not fully understood. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized, and its electronic properties can be tuned reversibly by strain engineering. This opens up new opportunities for tailoring the electronic properties of diamond for quantum applications.

The discovery of a new class of antifungal peptides is a significant advance in the fight against plant fungal pathogens. This work provides structural and functional insights into the mode of action of a structurally unique NCR peptide. It also demonstrates the potential of this class of peptides as a spray-on fungistat/fungicide.

The male–female reproductive interface is a critical site of interaction, and the extent of molecular continuity between the sexes is unknown. We show that the proteome of Drosophila sperm undergoes substantial changes after being transferred to the female reproductive tract. We also show that the female reproductive tract provides a source of proteins that support sperm viability during the prolonged period between copulation and fertilization. Our research provides a comprehensive characterization of the posttesticular life history of the Drosophila sperm proteome and expands our understanding of the critical process of sperm–FRT interactions. This work provides a foundation for future studies of the molecular basis of sperm–FRT interactions and the extent of molecular continuity between the sexes. (Show more)

Von Willebrand factor (VWF) is a large protein that is critical for hemostasis. It is synthesized in the endothelium and stored in platelets. In the event of bleeding, VWF is released from platelets and binds to the glycoprotein Ibα receptor on the surface of activated platelets. This binding promotes platelet aggregation and stops the bleeding. In von Willebrand disease (VWD), mutations in VWF cause a failure of VWF to bind to platelets. We show that the binding of VWF to platelets can be switched on demand, by application of force. This mechanism provides a mechanism for the pathophysiology of VWD.

The human microbiome is a complex ecosystem of bacteria that has been the focus of intense study for the past decade. However, the viral component of the microbiome has been more difficult to study, and the lack of a comprehensive database has hindered the ability to understand the role of viruses in human health. This study provides a comprehensive database of viruses associated with humans, which can be used to study the role of viruses in disease and to identify new viruses that may be pathogenic. The database includes over 45,000 unique virus taxa, with historically high per-genome completeness. It is available for download and can be used by the research community.

Aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) is one of the most important processes in the climate system. However, it is difficult to be well represented in current climate models. This is due to the complexity of the ACI process and the lack of observational capability. Here, we introduce a new instrument, the dual-field-of-view high-spectral-resolution lidar (HSRL), which can simultaneously measure aerosol and cloud properties. This instrument is capable of providing high-resolution observations of aerosols and clouds, especially water cloud microphysical properties. We demonstrate the scientific potential of this instrument by conducting a case study over Beijing. The observations show that the increased aerosol loading led to increased droplet number concentration and decreased droplet effective radius, which is consistent with expectations. However, the aerosol-induced cloud water increase caused by suppressed rain formation can be canceled out by enhanced evaporation. Thus, these observations constitute substantial and significant additions to understanding ACI. This technique is expected to represent a significant step forward in characterizing ACI. This paper is expected to be a significant contribution to the ACI research.

The temperature history of the Earth is a key factor in understanding the evolution of life. Here, we use the thermostability of reconstructed ancestral enzymes to determine the temperature history of the Earth over geological time. Our results suggest that the temperature of the Earth’s surface decreased over time, a finding consistent with both previous isotope-based and protein reconstruction-based interpretations. This study demonstrates the utility of integrating genomic, geologic, and paleontologic data to provide new insight into the coevolution of life and environment over Earth history. This approach may be extended to other systems to further our understanding of the evolution of life on Earth. (Show more)

Ion channels are the gatekeepers of ion flow. They are activated and deactivated by two gates, one at the intracellular end for fast channel opening/closing and the other at the selectivity filter for slow C-type inactivation/recovery. We found that the BK channel, which is a large-conductance calcium-activated potassium channel, lacks a classic activation gate at the intracellular end and normally shows no C-type inactivation. We induced C-type inactivation in BK channels and studied the relationship between activation/deactivation and C-type inactivation/recovery. We found that C-type inactivation in BK channels is state-dependent and that its extents and rates inversely correlate with channel-open probability. Because C-type inactivation can involve multiple conformational changes at the selectivity filter, we propose that the BK channel’s closing may represent an early conformational stage of C-type inactivation. Our findings provide insights into the mechanism of the BK channel’s unique properties. (Show more)

Malaria is one of the most devastating diseases in the world, with millions of deaths each year. The Plasmodium parasite invades the human red blood cell (RBC) to complete its life cycle. The invasion process is poorly understood, and the role of the parasite’s erythrocyte-binding antigen 175 (EBA175) in this process is unknown. Here, we show that EBA175 binding to glycophorin A (GPA) on the RBC surface leads to an increase in the tension of the red cell cytoskeleton and a reduction in the bending modulus of the membrane. These changes in the red cell biophysical properties are correlated with parasite invasion efficiency. This finding suggests that the malaria parasite primes the erythrocyte surface through its binding antigens, altering the biophysical nature of the target cell and thus reducing a critical energy barrier to invasion. This would constitute a major change in our concept of malaria parasite invasion, suggesting it is, in fact, a balance between parasite and host cell physical forces working together to facilitate entry. This work provides a new perspective on the invasion process and could lead to the development of new antimalarial strategies. (Show more)

Diamond is a unique material with a wide range of applications in electronics, photonics, and quantum technologies. It is also a promising material for the next generation of high-performance sensors. However, it is not easy to control the properties of diamond, especially its electronic and optical properties, because of its high hardness and low ductility. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized, or demetallized, by applying a small strain. This opens up new possibilities for controlling the electronic and optical properties of diamond. Our findings can be used to develop new devices and applications for diamond. They also provide a general framework for controlling the properties of other materials with high hardness and low ductility. This work is expected to be of interest to researchers in materials science, physics, and engineering.

Influenza virus is a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. In temperate regions, seasonal influenza outbreaks correlate closely with decreases in ambient humidity. However, the impact of low humidity on host response to influenza virus infection and disease outcome remains unclear. Here, we show that housing mice in low humidity makes mice more susceptible to severe disease following respiratory challenge with influenza A virus. We find that exposure to dry air impairs mucociliary clearance, innate antiviral defense, and tissue repair. Moreover, disease exacerbated by low humidity was ameliorated in caspase-1/11–deficient mice, independent of viral burden. Single-cell RNA sequencing revealed that induction of IFN-stimulated genes in response to viral infection was diminished in multiple cell types in the lung of mice housed in low humidity condition. These results indicate that exposure to dry air impairs host defense against influenza infection, reduces tissue repair, and inflicts caspase-dependent disease pathology. Our findings provide mechanistic insights into the impact of low humidity on influenza virus infection and disease outcome. They also suggest that low humidity may be a modifiable risk factor for influenza virus infection and disease severity. Our study provides a rationale for the development of strategies to mitigate the impact of low humidity

We report the first intracranial evidence for the merge operation, which is the fundamental operation underlying the construction of syntactic structures. We also provide evidence for a neural implementation of this operation. Our results suggest that the brain compresses syntactically well-formed sequences of words into a hierarchy of nested phrases. This is consistent with the idea that the brain is a bottom-up parser of the incoming language stream. Our findings have implications for our understanding of the neural basis of language and sentence processing. They also have implications for theories of sentence processing that assume that the brain is a top-down parser of the language stream. Our results provide a starting point for future investigations of the neural implementation of linguistic theory. (Show more)

The canonical Wnt pathway is a major pathway for the regulation of development. Axin is a key component of the pathway, and its function is to convert signals at the plasma membrane to signals inhibiting the degradation of β-catenin, leading to its accumulation and specific gene activation. We show here that the two forms of Axin, Axin1 and Axin2, are similar at the protein level and genetically redundant. We show that the two forms of Axin are regulated differently on the transcriptional and proteostatic level, which confers differential responsiveness that can be used in tissue-specific regulation. Such subtle features may distinguish other redundant gene pairs that are commonly found in vertebrates through gene knockout experiments. This work may help to understand the role of redundant genes in biology.

This study provides a detailed characterization of a brain circuit that may contribute to overeating and obesity. The lateral hypothalamus is a brain region that is involved in the regulation of feeding. In this study, we show that stimulation of this region can induce vigorous eating in sated animals. We also show that this circuit is involved in overeating, as lesions of this circuit in mice prevented the development of overeating. This study provides a detailed characterization of a brain circuit that may contribute to overeating and obesity.

Nitrogen is a key nutrient for plant growth and productivity, but its availability is limited in many agricultural systems. In this work, we have developed a system for the control of nitrogen fixation in plants, which allows for the precise timing and location of nitrogenase activity. This system could be used to control the activity of bacteria that fix nitrogen in the atmosphere, and thus could be used to increase the efficiency of nitrogen use in agriculture. This work represents a key milestone toward the development of a synthetic plant-controlled symbiosis in which the bacteria fix N2 only when in contact with the desired host plant and are prevented from interaction with nontarget plant species. This work also represents a key step toward the development of a synthetic plant-controlled symbiosis in which the bacteria fix N2 only when in contact with the desired host plant and are prevented from interaction with nontarget plant species. This work could be used to increase the efficiency of nitrogen use in agriculture. (Show more)

We study the effectiveness of a community-based monitoring program in the Peruvian Amazon. We find that the program reduced tree cover loss in the communities that participated in the program. However, the estimated effects are imprecise, and the results are not statistically significant. The results suggest that the program may contribute to sustainable forest management.

Hearing is a fundamental sense of many animals, including all mammals, birds, some reptiles, amphibians, fish, and arthropods. The auditory organs of these animals are extremely diverse in anatomy after hundreds of millions of years of evolution, yet they are all made up of cellular tissue and are morphologically part of the bodies of animals. Here, we show that hearing in the orb-weaving spider Larinioides sclopetarius is not constrained by the organism’s body but is extended through outsourcing hearing to its extended phenotype, the proteinaceous, self-manufactured orb web. We find that the spider’s web acts as a hyperacute acoustic antenna to sense the motion of web threads, which allows the spider to remotely detect and localize the source of an incoming airborne acoustic wave. By outsourcing its acoustic sensors to its web, the spider is released from body size constraints and permits the araneid spider to increase its sound-sensitive surface area enormously, up to 10,000 times greater than the spider itself. We show that a rapid phaseout of fossil-fuel-related emissions and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources are needed to save millions of lives, restore aerosol-perturbed rainfall patterns, and limit global warming to 2 °C.

The receptor-binding domain (RBD) of the spike protein is the target of the neutralizing antibodies that protect against severe COVID-19. We engineered the RBD of the Wuhan-Hu-1 sequence to increase its yield, affinity, and immunogenicity. The engineered RBD was presented on a virus-like particle (VLP) and showed reduced weight loss in hamsters upon viral challenge. These results suggest that the engineered RBD can be used to design a vaccine that can be manufactured at large scale and can protect against the variants of concern. This engineered RBD can be used in combination with other vaccine candidates or as a standalone vaccine. We report the identification of a ligand–receptor pair that is involved in the development of neural crest-derived tissues. We show that the small secreted ALKAL proteins are ligands for the zebrafish homolog of the anaplastic lymphoma kinase (ALK) and the human homolog of the leukocyte tyrosine kinase (LTK). We demonstrate that the ALKALs are involved in the development of zebrafish iridophores and that the ALKALs are required for zebrafish neural crest development. Our results provide evidence for the involvement of ALKALs in the development of neural crest-derived tissues.

Plague is one of the most devastating diseases in human history, and the pathogen that causes it has been a constant threat to humanity. The emergence of Yersinia pestis, the agent of the Black Death, is a classic example of how a pathogen can cause a pandemic and cause widespread devastation. Here, we present a large dataset of ancient Y. pestis genomes, which provide insights into the early evolution of this pathogen and its adaptation to different hosts and environments. Our results suggest that the emergence of plague was a complex process that involved multiple steps of adaptation and diversification. This study also reveals the presence of a flea-adapted form of plague in Iberia, which was previously only found in the Caucasus and the Volga regions. These data provide insights into the early history of plague and its adaptation to different hosts and environments. (Show more)

This work examined the relationship between men’s and women’s endorsement of the culturally idealized form of masculinity—hegemonic masculinity (HM)—and their support for Donald Trump, the 45th president of the United States. Consistent with our theoretical backdrop, HM was associated with support for Trump, over and above political party affiliation, gender, race, and education, in the days (Studies 1 and 2) and months (Studies 3 through 6) following the 2016 American presidential election. In addition, HM was associated with less trust in the government, more sexism, more racism, and more xenophobia but continued to predict unique variance in evaluations of Trump when controlling for each of these factors. The findings highlight the importance of psychological examinations of masculinity as a cultural ideology to understand how men’s and women’s endorsement of HM legitimizes patriarchal dominance and reinforces gender, race, and class-based hierarchies via candidate support. The findings also have implications for understanding the 2020 American presidential election.

The management of agricultural systems has a profound impact on the quantity and quality of soil organic carbon (SOC). In this study, we show that the management of annual cropping systems on a Midwestern Mollisol can be optimized to increase SOC storage and the quality of SOC. We found that the integration of legumes and manure into annual cropping systems, as well as rotational grazing of pastures, can increase SOC storage and the quality of SOC. These results highlight the potential of well-managed grasslands to sequester carbon and provide a framework for the development of climate-smart agricultural systems. The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need for a better understanding of the risk of spillover of viruses from animals to humans. We have developed a framework to identify and prioritize wildlife viruses with the greatest potential to spill over and spread to humans. The SpillOver platform is a living database that can be used by policy makers and health scientists to inform research and public health interventions for prevention and rapid control of disease outbreaks. SpillOver is a living, interactive database that can be refined over time to continue to improve the quality and public availability of information on viral threats to human health. We hope that SpillOver will be used to inform the development of strategies to prevent future outbreaks of zoonotic disease.

Nectar is the reward that flowers offer to pollinators for visitation. The color of nectar is a key trait that attracts pollinators to flowers. Here, we show that the red color of the nectar of Nesocodon mauritianus is derived from a previously undescribed alkaloid. We also identify a mechanism for the production of this color. This work provides insights into the evolution of the red color of nectar and the role of alkaloids in this process.

We present a genome-wide analysis of a group of individuals from southern Germany dating to the late 5th/early 6th century AD. Our data indicate that the genetic ancestry of men is mostly of northern and central European origin, while women exhibit a very high genetic heterogeneity. This heterogeneity includes signals of genetic ancestry ranging from western Europe to East Asia. Particularly striking are women with artificial skull deformations; the analysis of their collective genetic ancestry suggests an origin in southeastern Europe. In addition, functional variants revealed that they also differed in visible characteristics. This example of female-biased migration indicates that complex demographic processes during the Early Medieval period may have contributed in an unexpected way to shape the modern European genetic landscape.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a newly emerged pathogen that causes ∼36% fatality in infected patients. To understand how bat coronaviruses transmit to humans, we investigated the receptor usage and cell entry activity of the virus-surface spike proteins of HKU4 and HKU5. We found that dipeptidyl peptidase 4 (DPP4), the receptor for MERS-CoV, is also the receptor for HKU4, but not HKU5. Despite sharing a common receptor, MERS-CoV and HKU4 spikes demonstrated functional differences. First, whereas MERS-CoV prefers human DPP4 over bat DPP4 as its receptor, HKU4 shows the opposite trend. Second, in the absence of exogenous proteases, both MERS-CoV and HKU4 spikes mediate pseudovirus entry into bat cells, whereas only MERS-CoV spike, but not HKU4 spike, mediates pseudovirus entry into human cells. Thus, MERS-CoV, but not HKU4, has adapted to use human cells for efficient human cell entry, contributing to the enhanced pathogenesis of MERS-CoV in humans. These results establish DPP4

We describe the use of a global cloud-based metagenomic sequencing platform to investigate a large periurban hospital in Cambodia. We identified a variety of vector-borne, zoonotic, and emerging pathogens responsible for undifferentiated fevers in this population. We found that chikungunya virus presaged a larger national outbreak of more than 6,000 cases. Pathogen-agnostic mNGS investigation of febrile persons in resource-scarce Southeast Asia is feasible and revealing of a diverse pathogen landscape. Coordinated and ongoing mNGS pathogen surveillance can better identify the breadth of endemic, zoonotic, or emerging pathogens and deployment of rapid public health response. This approach can be used to investigate other resource-scarce settings to better understand the pathogen landscape and mitigate epidemics. (Show more)

The human genome is replicated in a complex process that involves the synthesis of Okazaki fragments. The lagging strand template is replicated by DNA polymerase δ (pol δ) in a processive manner, but the stability of the pol δ holoenzyme is unknown. Here, we report the results of a series of kinetic studies that provide a detailed picture of the processivity and stability of the pol δ holoenzyme. Our results indicate that pol δ maintains a loose association with PCNA while replicating DNA. Such behavior has profound implications on Okazaki fragment synthesis in humans as it limits the processivity of pol δ on undamaged DNA and promotes the rapid dissociation of pol δ from PCNA on stalling at a DNA lesion. Our results also suggest that the human pol δ holoenzyme is more stable than the S. cerevisiae pol δ holoenzyme. This difference may be important for the replication of the human genome.

The origin of life is one of the most important problems in science. In this paper, we describe the first successful in vitro evolution of an RNA polymerase ribozyme, which can replicate RNA. This work represents a major step toward the reconstruction of RNA-based life in the laboratory.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods with economic and demographic data and find that three factors predict neighborhood improvement. First, neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements. Second, neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements. Third, neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our method can be used to monitor the physical changes in cities over time and to study the causes of urban change. We hope that our method will be useful to urban scholars and practitioners.

COVID-19 is a severe disease with high mortality. The treatment is still in the stage of clinical trial. In this study, we found that tocilizumab, which is used for rheumatoid arthritis, is effective in the treatment of severe and critical COVID-19 patients. It is expected that this study will provide a new idea for the treatment of COVID-19.

Copper is an essential micronutrient, but it is also toxic at high concentrations. The mechanisms by which fungi maintain copper homeostasis are not well understood. Here we report the discovery of a fungal natural product, xanthocillin, that binds copper and has antimicrobial properties. The existence of the xanthocillin biosynthetic gene cluster in several filamentous fungi suggests that this mechanism of copper homeostasis is widespread in fungi. The discovery of this mechanism of copper homeostasis has implications for our understanding of fungal interactions with competing microbes. This work also provides a model for the discovery of other metal-binding fungal natural products. (Show more)

The formation of silica minerals in the martian interior is a key question in the search for evidence of past aqueous activity. The detection of tridymite in a sedimentary rock at Gale crater, Mars, is a significant finding. Tridymite is a high-temperature, high-pressure polymorph of silica that is commonly associated with silicic volcanism. The detection of tridymite in a sedimentary rock at Gale crater, Mars, is a significant finding.

Frost damage is a major threat to the productivity of forests and agriculture, and the frequency of late-spring frosts (LSFs) is increasing in many regions. We show that the geographic distribution of LSFs is linked to the leaf-out and leaf-freezing strategies of trees, and that the resistance strategies of trees are linked to the vulnerability of forests to LSFs. Our findings can help decision-makers in land management, forestry, agriculture, and insurance policy to adapt to the changing spring-frost risk.

Th17 cells are critical for the pathogenesis of certain types of inflammatory bowel disease. However, the role of Th17 cells in the development of disease is unknown. Here, we show that the development of colitis requires the transition of a subset of Th17 cells to Th1-like cells. This transition requires the transcription factor T-bet, but not the IFN-γ receptor. Th17 cells can provide “help” for the development of classic Th1 cells. These results indicate that Th17 cells are potent mediators of colitis pathogenesis. Thus, targeting Th17 cells may be a useful strategy for the treatment of inflammatory bowel disease.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a devastating neurodegenerative disease with no cure. The disease is caused by mutations in genes encoding motor neuron proteins, and the disease process is thought to be driven by motor neuron toxicity. However, the mechanisms of motor neuron toxicity are not fully understood. Here, we report a method to rapidly produce motor neuron-like cells from living patients with ALS. This will enable high-throughput screening of compounds to identify those that alleviate motor neuron toxicity and thus may be useful in the treatment of ALS. This method will also enable the study of the disease process in ALS. This will be a powerful tool for ALS research. (Show more)

The gut microbiota of Ixodes scapularis ticks plays a critical role in the transmission of human pathogens. However, the mechanisms by which pathogens influence the tick microbiota are poorly understood. Here, we show that the human pathogen Anaplasma phagocytophilum induces ticks to express antifreeze glycoprotein, which alters the gut microbiota and facilitates the transmission of Anaplasma. We demonstrate that the protein, which is expressed in response to Anaplasma infection, binds the terminal d-alanine residue of the peptidoglycan cell wall of bacteria, resulting in altered permeability and the capacity of bacteria to form biofilms. These findings provide insight into the mechanisms by which pathogens influence the gut microbiota of their vector. They also have implications for the development of strategies to control the spread of human pathogens. (Show more)

The evolution of the avian tail is one of the most important transitions in the history of birds. The discovery of a new basal pygostylian, Jinguofortis, adds important information about the origin of the short tail. The mosaic evolution of the mosaic tail is a common theme in the evolution of birds.

The climate system is a complex system, and it is difficult to understand the behavior of the system without a detailed understanding of the processes that are involved. In this paper, we show that one of the processes that is important in the climate system is the increase in water vapor in the stratosphere with increasing temperature in the troposphere. This increase in water vapor in the stratosphere is a feedback that increases the amount of energy that is absorbed by the climate system.

The evolution of color in animals is one of the most striking features of the animal kingdom. In this study, we show that the color of anurans (frogs and toads) has evolved multiple times during their evolutionary history, and that this color is due to the presence of a class of proteins that bind biliverdin. These proteins, hereafter named biliverdin-binding serpins, are most similar to human alpha-1-antitrypsin, but with a remarkable functional diversification. Our results present molecular and functional evidence of recurrent evolution of chlorosis, describe a biliverdin-binding protein in vertebrates, and introduce a function for a member of the serpin superfamily, the largest and most ubiquitous group of protease inhibitors. These findings provide a molecular basis for the evolution of color in animals. (Show more)

Breast cancer is the most common cancer in women worldwide. The development of breast cancer is associated with a loss of the ability to form tumors, which is associated with the presence of breast cancer stem cells (BCSCs). In this study, we show that hypoxia induces expression of the m6A demethylase AlkB homolog 5 (ALKBH5), which in turn increases the expression of NANOG, a gene that encodes a pluripotency factor. We also show that ALKBH5 expression is required for the induction of BCSC properties by hypoxia. Thus, ALKBH5 may be a potential therapeutic target for breast cancer.

The Bible is one of the most widely read books in the world. The first pocket Bibles were made in the 13th century, and the source of the parchment, often called “uterine vellum,” has been a long-standing controversy. Here, we report a simple and objective method to identify the animal origin of parchment. The method is a variant on zooarchaeology by mass spectrometry (ZooMS) peptide mass fingerprinting but extracts protein from the parchment surface by using an electrostatic charge generated by gentle rubbing of a PVC eraser on the membrane surface. Using this method, we analyzed 72 pocket Bibles originating in France, England, and Italy and 293 additional parchment samples that bracket this period. We found no evidence for the use of unexpected animals; however, we did identify the use of more than one mammal species in a single manuscript, consistent with the local availability of hides. These results suggest that ultrafine vellum does not necessarily derive from the use of abortive or newborn animals with ultrathin hides, but could equally well reflect a production process that allowed the skins of maturing animals of several species to be rendered into vellum of equal quality and fineness. The end-Permian mass extinction was the most severe extinction event in the last 542 My. The cause of the extinction is unknown, but the timing, duration, and intensity of the perturbation are well constrained. The carbon cycle was also perturbed, but the timing, magnitude, and duration of the changes are less well constrained. Here, we provide a precise age model for the extinction and its aftermath, which will allow a refined evaluation of the relative roles of rate-dependent processes contributing to the extinction. This will allow insight into postextinction ecosystem expansion, and establish an accurate time point for evaluating the plausibility of trigger and kill mechanisms. The age model will also allow a better understanding of the links between the end-Permian extinction and the subsequent rise of the mammals.

The intestinal epithelium is the primary barrier between the host and the external environment. It is also the first line of defense against invading pathogens and the maintenance of homeostasis. However, the intestinal epithelium is also the primary target of many diseases, including inflammatory bowel disease (IBD). IBD is a chronic inflammatory disease that affects the intestinal epithelium, leading to the destruction of the intestinal barrier and the release of proinflammatory factors into the body. In this study, we found that retinoic acid-related orphan receptor α (RORα) is crucial for maintaining intestinal homeostasis and attenuating nuclear factor κB (NF-κB) transcriptional activity in the intestinal epithelium. RORα/HDAC3-mediated attenuation of NF-κB signaling controls the balance of inflammatory responses, and therapeutic strategies targeting this epigenetic regulation could be beneficial to the treatment of chronic inflammatory diseases, including IBD.
