The spike glycoprotein of SARS-CoV-2 is the primary target for the immune system and for neutralizing antibodies. We have determined the structure of the SARS-CoV-2 spike in complex with the receptor ACE2, and we have compared the structure of the spike in the presence and absence of the D614G mutation. We find that the D614G mutation is associated with a more open conformation of the spike, which may facilitate binding to the receptor. This work provides insights into the mechanism of action of the D614G mutation and may help to explain the increased transmissibility of the virus. (Show more)

We consider repeated games with tail-measurable payoffs, i.e., when the payoffs depend only on what happens in the long run. We show that every repeated game with tail-measurable payoffs admits an ε-equilibrium, for every ε>0, provided that the set of players is finite or countably infinite and the action sets are finite. The proof relies on techniques from stochastic games and from alternating-move games with Borel-measurable payoffs.

COVID-19 has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States. We estimate that, in the absence of the pandemic, life expectancy at birth would have been 78.6 y in 2020, and at age 65 y, 81.9 y. The Black and Latino populations are estimated to experience declines in life expectancy at birth of 2.10 and 3.05 y, respectively, both of which are several times the 0.68-y reduction for Whites. Latinos, who have consistently experienced lower mortality than Whites, would see their more than 3-y survival advantage reduced to less than 1 y. These projections imply an increase of nearly 40% in the Black−White life expectancy gap, from 3.6 y to over 5 y, thereby eliminating progress made in reducing this differential since 2006.

The chemical properties of atoms are the basis of chemistry. They are also the key to understanding the chemistry of compounds. In this work, we show that the chemical properties of atoms, electronegativity and chemical hardness, decrease with pressure, and that the elements preceding Ni, Pd, and Pt become pseudo–noble-gas atoms with a closed d-shell configuration, and the elements right after them (Cu, Ag, Zn, and Cd) become highly electropositive. We show the explicative and predictive power of our electronegativity and chemical hardness scales. Our results are of interest to chemists, physicists, and materials scientists.

Climate change is expected to increase the frequency of extreme fire events, which could lead to a large increase in carbon emissions. However, human ignitions and fire suppression can also reduce fire activity, which could reduce the rate of carbon loss. We show that both climate and human factors can affect fire activity, and that the relative importance of each depends on the trajectory of emissions. Our results suggest that climate–carbon cycle feedbacks are most effective at slowing global warming under lower emission scenarios. Our study highlights the importance of fire in the carbon cycle and the need to understand the effects of climate change and human activities on fire regimes. This is important for the global carbon cycle, climate, and the services that ecosystems provide.

The provision of nutrients to specific symbiotic microbes is a widespread strategy used by animals to maintain the health of their tissues. However, the mechanisms underlying this process are poorly understood. Here, we show that the squid Euprymna scolopes regulates the activities of its symbiotic luminescent bacteria through the strategic provision of a single glycan, which is catabolized only at night. This glycan is delivered to the squid’s immune cells, where it is released into the symbiotic organ, where it is catabolized by the bacteria. The catabolism of this glycan is required for the persistence of the symbionts and for the acidification of the symbiotic organ, which enhances the luminescence of the symbionts. This study provides a mechanistic understanding of the role of glycans in the regulation of symbiont populations and in the maintenance of the pH of the habitat of the symbionts. We propose that this strategy may be used by other animal hosts. (Show more)

Text data are ubiquitous, and the need for methods to identify latent patterns is growing. We introduce a method to identify topics in a corpus and represent documents as topic sequences. We use this method to identify latent topics in a prominent example of underutilized text: the US National Violent Death Reporting System. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model topics in text data. It can be used to identify latent patterns in many domains, including social media, news, and medical records. It can also be used to identify latent topics in structured data, such as medical records, and to model the gender bias of topics. Our method can be extended to other types of data, such as images and videos. It can be used to identify latent patterns in many domains, including social media, news, and medical records. It can also be used to identify latent topics in structured data, such as medical records, and to model the gender bias of topics. Our method can be extended to other types of data, such as images and videos.

The Black Death, which originated in Asia, arrived in the Mediterranean harbors of Europe in 1347 CE, via the land and sea trade routes of the ancient Silk Road system. This epidemic marked the start of the second plague pandemic, which lasted in Europe until the early 19th century. We show that the climate conditions in Asia, where the disease originated, were favorable for the survival of Yersinia pestis, the bacterium that causes plague, for centuries before the arrival of the disease in Europe. We also show that the climate conditions in Europe, where the disease established itself, were favorable for the survival of the bacterium for centuries after the arrival of the disease. Our results suggest that the Black Death was the consequence of repeated reintroductions of the bacterium into European harbors from Asian reservoirs, with a delay of 15 ± 1 y. This suggests that the Black Death was not the consequence of a single introduction of the bacterium into Europe. (Show more)

We report the discovery of a densovirus (Parvoviridae) as the likely cause of the asteroid wasting disease (SSWD) that has been devastating the Northeast Pacific Coast population of asteroids. The virus was detected in symptomatic asteroids and in sediments, suggesting that it is spread by the water column. The discovery of the virus in museum specimens of asteroids from 1942 provides evidence that the disease has been present on the North American Pacific Coast for at least 72 y. SSaDV is therefore the most promising candidate disease agent responsible for asteroid mass mortality.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is one of the most aggressive forms of leukemia, and there is an urgent need for novel and more efficient therapies. We show here that antibodies targeting the interleukin 1 receptor accessory protein (IL1RAP) are effective in xenograft models of human AML. We demonstrate that effector-cell–mediated killing is essential for the observed therapeutic effects, and that natural killer cells constitute a critical human effector cell type. We also show that an antibody targeting IL1RAP can suppress the proliferation of primary human AML cells. Hence, IL1RAP can be efficiently targeted with an antibody capable of both achieving antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity and blocking of IL-1 signaling as modes of action. These results provide important evidence in support of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML. This work also provides a proof of principle for the use of antibodies as a treatment modality for AML. (Show more)

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across the island, from the north to the south, from the east to the west. We found that the Malagasy population is a mixture of Bantu and Austronesian populations, with a limited contribution from Europe and the Middle East. The distribution of African and Asian ancestry across the island reveals that the admixture was sex biased and happened heterogeneously across Madagascar, suggesting independent colonization of Madagascar from Africa and Asia rather than settlement by an already admixed population. In addition, a few centuries is sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. This study provides a comprehensive view of the genomic diversity of Madagascar. It is a unique resource for the scientific community. It will be used to study the history of Madagascar and the Indian Ocean. It will also be used to study the human population dynamics and the genetic consequences of the human migrations. It will be used to study the genetic consequences of the climate change. Bacteria have evolved small RNAs (sRNAs) to regulate numerous biological processes and stress responses. While sRNAs generally are considered to be “noncoding,” a few have been found to also encode a small protein. Here we describe one such dual-function RNA that modulates carbon utilization in Escherichia coli. The RNA encodes a 28-amino acid protein that interacts with the aerobic glycerol-3-phosphate dehydrogenase, GlpD, and increases dehydrogenase activity. The RNA also interferes with the ability of another sRNA to repress the ntax operon, which encodes the enzymes required for the synthesis of the cell envelope. These results demonstrate that the translation and base-pairing functions of the RNA compete. The RNA is the first to be described that encodes a protein and interferes with the ability of another sRNA to repress its target genes. This RNA is also the first to be described that interferes with the ability of another sRNA to repress its target genes.

Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants.

Crop experts are the primary source of information on crop status. However, their assessments are subjective and categorical, and are not easily amenable to quantitative analysis. We show that the USDA Crop Progress and Condition survey, which is based on the subjective assessments of thousands of crop experts, can be transformed into a continuous, probabilistic variable that can be used to monitor crop status and provide earlier and more precise predictions of crop yields than official forecasts released midseason. We also discuss the origin and interpretation of existing spatial and temporal biases in the survey data. Our findings have implications for the design of large-scale continuous monitoring systems, and for the development of early warning systems for agricultural production anomalies.

Language is a complex cognitive ability that is unique to humans. It is thought to be supported by a mechanism that maintains information in working memory over short periods of time. Here we propose a mechanism for memory that is based on changes in the excitability of neurons. We show that changes in the strength of synaptic connections are not required for memory. Instead, information is maintained in adaptive conductances that reduce firing rates. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it can bind linguistic features over time. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

Soil respiration is a major component of the global carbon cycle, yet its response to climate change is poorly understood. In this study, we synthesize the largest global dataset to date of soil respiration, moisture, and temperature measurements, totaling >3,800 observations representing 27 temperature manipulation studies, spanning nine biomes and over 2 decades of warming. Our analysis reveals no significant differences in the temperature sensitivity of soil respiration between control and warmed plots in all biomes, with the exception of deserts and boreal forests. Thus, our data provide limited evidence of acclimation of soil respiration to experimental warming in several major biome types, contrary to the results from multiple single-site studies. Our analysis adds a unique cross-biome perspective on the temperature response of soil respiration, information critical to improving our mechanistic understanding of how soil carbon dynamics change with climatic warming. The molecular evolution of plastid genomes is a key component of the evolution of photosynthesis and the origin of eukaryotes. Here, we present a model of the molecular evolution of plastid genomes during the transition from autotrophy to a nonphotosynthetic parasitic lifestyle. We show that the transition to obligate parasitism relaxes functional constraints on plastid genes in a stepwise manner. Our findings suggest that the molecular evolution of plastid genomes is a dynamic process that is shaped by the interplay between macroevolutionary events and microevolutionary processes. The 2015–2017 Cape Town drought is a stark reminder of the vulnerability of cities to climate change. We show that anthropogenic climate change increased the probability of the 2015–2017 rainfall deficit by a factor of five to six. The probability of such an event will increase from 0.7 to 80% by the year 2100 under a high-emission scenario (SSP5-8.5). This highlights the strong sensitivity of the drought risk in SSA to future anthropogenic emissions. Our results also show that the probability of a rainfall deficit in SSA is higher than in other regions, such as the United States, and that the risk of drought in SSA is expected to increase more than in other regions. This is due to the combination of a high baseline risk and a high sensitivity of the region to anthropogenic climate change.

The discovery of quasicrystals in the aftermath of the first nuclear test, the Trinity test, has been a major event in the history of science. Here, we report the discovery of a hitherto unknown composition of icosahedral quasicrystal in the trinitite, the material that resulted from the test explosion. The discovery of this quasicrystal, which was formed in the seconds after the explosion, provides a link between the discovery of quasicrystals and the history of the atomic bomb.

Photosynthesis is the most important process on Earth, and the light-harvesting pigments are the key to its success. The biosynthesis of these pigments is highly conserved across all life, and the formation of the fifth isocyclic ring, the so-called B-ring, is one of the most enigmatic steps. This reaction is catalyzed by two unrelated enzymes, one of which is O2 sensitive, whereas the other is O2 dependent. Here, we show that the O2-dependent enzyme is a multisubunit protein, and that the O2-sensitive enzyme is a homodimer. We also show that the O2-dependent enzyme has three classes, and that the O2 sensitivity of the enzyme is determined by the subunit composition. These findings provide a framework for understanding the evolution of the B-ring formation. (Show more)

Neuroinflammation is a major pathological feature of multiple sclerosis (MS), and it is well known to be associated with neurodegenerative diseases. Neuroinflammation is a complex process that involves multiple cell types, including microglia, astrocytes, and neurons. Neuroinflammation is also known to be regulated by a kinase called neurokinase-related protein kinase 1 (Nrp1), which is known to be involved in the regulation of neuroinflammation. In this study, we found that neuroinflammation is regulated by a kinase called apoptosis signal-regulating kinase 1 (ASK1), which is known to be involved in neuroinflammation. We also found that ASK1 is involved in the regulation of neuroinflammation in a cell-type-specific manner. Our findings suggest that ASK1 is a promising therapeutic target for reducing neuroinflammation. This study also provides a better understanding of the role of ASK1 in neuroinflammation. (Show more)

The 2012–2014 drought in California is the driest period in the state’s instrumental record. We show that the probability of drought has increased in the past two decades, and that this increase is very likely due to human activities.

Autism is a complex disorder with a multifactorial inheritance pattern. Therefore, it is difficult to identify the causal paths that lead to the core symptoms of autism. In this study, we used a reversal-learning task to measure behavioral flexibility in Drosophila and determined the effects of loss-of-function mutations in multiple autism-risk gene homologs in flies. We found that mutations of five autism-risk genes with diversified molecular functions all led to a similar phenotype of behavioral inflexibility indicated by impaired reversal-learning. These reversal-learning defects resulted from the inability to forget or rather, specifically, to activate Rac1 (Ras-related C3 botulinum toxin substrate 1)-dependent forgetting. Thus, behavior-evoked activation of Rac1-dependent forgetting has a converging function for autism-risk genes. Our findings provide a mechanistic understanding of the behavioral inflexibility that is a core symptom of autism. They also provide a potential target for the development of a behavioral intervention for autism. (Show more)

This work is the first to our knowledge to examine the prevalence of negativity biases in news content across a large number of countries and continents. It finds that, on average, news content is overwhelmingly negative. It also finds that individual-level variation in responsiveness to news content is considerable. The results help account for the prevalence of negative news content, and suggest that there may be reason to reconsider the conventional journalistic wisdom that “if it bleeds, it leads.”

Stormorken syndrome is a rare, multisystemic disorder that was first described in 2014. The underlying cause of the disease is unknown, and the clinical features of the disorder are highly variable. Here, we report the identification of mutations in the components of the store-operated Ca2+ channel complex that are associated with Stormorken syndrome. Our findings provide insights into the molecular basis of Stormorken syndrome and related conditions, and suggest new therapeutic strategies for patients with Stormorken syndrome and related conditions. These findings also advance our understanding of the molecular function of the CRAC channel and the regulation of store-operated Ca2+ entry. (Show more)

The spreading of protein aggregates is a key feature of several major neurodegenerative diseases, including Huntington’s disease. However, the mechanisms underlying this spreading are unknown. Here we show that the spreading of aggregates in a Drosophila model of Huntington’s disease is dependent on the internalization of aggregates, which is in turn dependent on endocytosis. We also show that the spreading of aggregates is non–cell-autonomous, and that the internalization of aggregates is required for the spread of disease. Finally, we show that the release of aggregates requires fusion protein 1, demonstrating that active release and uptake of aggregates are important elements of spreading and disease progression. These results provide insights into the mechanisms underlying the spreading of aggregates in neurodegenerative diseases. They also provide a platform for the development of new therapeutic strategies for neurodegenerative diseases. (Show more)

The immune system of bats is considered to be highly evolved to protect them from pathogens. However, the immune system of bats is not immune to pathogens. In this study, we identified a protein, MTX, which is highly concentrated in the submandibular salivary gland of the bat, Myotis pilosus. MTX is a potent immunosuppressant that inhibits the epoxide hydrolase function of leukotriene-A4 hydrolase (LTA4H) to inhibit LTA4 hydrolysis and the generation of leukotriene B4 (LTB4), a potent lipid chemoattractant for host defense against infection. MTX potently inhibited proinflammatory proteases to induce immune tolerance and maintain high stability. MTX exacerbated influenza A virus (IAV) infection and pathogenicity in mice. This study provides deeper insight into immunologically privileged sites for microbial community residence in bats and supports the therapeutic potential of targeting MTX-LTA4H. (Show more)

Cancer is a disease of the cell cycle, and the cell cycle is fueled by the one-carbon unit derived from the folate cycle. We have developed a small-molecule inhibitor of the enzyme that converts serine to the one-carbon unit, and have shown that it blocks cancer cell growth. We have also shown that the one-carbon unit is required for lymphoma cell growth, and that this requirement is rooted in defective glycine import. Thus, we have identified a metabolic vulnerability of lymphoma cells that can be exploited for cancer therapy.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a devastating neurodegenerative disease with no known cause or cure. Here, we show that the proteins that are colocalized with mutant superoxide dismutase 1 (SOD1), TDP-43, and Fused in Sarcoma (FUS) in the brain and spinal cord of patients with ALS are not merely a subset of the native interaction partners of these three proteins, which are themselves supersaturated. Rather, the inclusion bodies that contain these proteins are the result of a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons, and thus prone to aggregation upon a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in this specific setting. Our results suggest that the inclusion bodies in various forms of ALS result from a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons, and thus prone to aggregation upon a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in this specific setting. This metastable state may be a common feature of neurodegenerative diseases, and may provide a target for therapeutic intervention. (Show more)

We present a 2D photonic crystal system for interacting with cold atoms. The photonic crystal is designed to produce unconventional atom–light interaction behaviors, including anisotropic emission, suppressed spontaneous decay, and photon-mediated atom–atom interactions controlled by the position of the atomic array relative to the photonic crystal. The device configuration also enables application of optical tweezers for controlled placement of atoms. The photonic crystal device can be fabricated reliably from a 200-nm silicon nitride device layer using a lithography-based process, producing predicted optical properties in transmission and reflection measurements. These 2D photonic crystal devices can be readily deployed to experiments for many-body physics with neutral atoms and engineering of exotic quantum matter. The photonic crystal device can be used for a wide range of applications, including quantum information processing, quantum simulation, and quantum sensing. The Cretaceous is a key time in the evolution of plants. It is during this time that the first flowering plants appeared and diversified. The origin of the flowering plants is poorly understood, and there are many different hypotheses. One of the most controversial is the hypothesis that the early flowering plants were aquatic. Here we present a detailed study of the Cretaceous flowering plant Montsechia, which is the earliest known flowering plant. Our results support the hypothesis that the early flowering plants were aquatic.

The human parvovirus B19 (B19V) is a ubiquitous pathogen that causes a number of conditions, such as fifth disease in children and arthritis and arthralgias in adults. The most recent common ancestor of all B19V has been dated to the early 1800s, and it has been suggested that genotype 1, the most common B19V genotype, only started circulating in the 1960s. Here we present 10 ancient B19V genomes (∼0.5–6.9 kya) from Eurasia and Greenland. We find that B19V has been associated with humans for a long time, and that the most recent common ancestor of all B19V is dated to ∼12.6 kya. We also find that the recombination event that formed genotype 2 occurred ∼5.0–6.8 kya. This study emphasizes the importance of ancient viral sequences for our understanding of virus evolution and phylogenetics. (Abridged)

Sea level is rising around the world, and the rate of rise is increasing. This is a well-known phenomenon, but its causes are still the subject of debate. In this paper, we show that the rate of sea level rise is increasing, and that this increase is consistent with the well-known effects of human-induced climate change.

Pain is a normal part of life, but it is not normal to get more pain as you get older. In this paper, we show that pain is not getting better with age in America today. In fact, pain is getting worse with age for those born after 1950. This is a mystery, and it has important implications for healthcare.

The structure of the enzyme-catalyzed reaction intermediate is a key determinant of the reaction pathway and the rate and mechanism of the reaction. Here, we use NMR-assisted crystallography to characterize the structure of the tryptophan synthase α-aminoacrylate intermediate, a defining species for pyridoxal-5′-phosphate–dependent enzymes that catalyze β-elimination and replacement reactions. The structure of this intermediate is used to understand the reaction pathway and the role of the cofactor and substrate in the reaction. This work highlights the power of NMR-assisted crystallography for mechanistic enzymology. (Show more)

Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) is a severe respiratory disease caused by a newly identified coronavirus. There is no specific treatment for MERS, and the high mortality rate of the disease highlights the need for the development of effective antiviral therapies. Here, we show that remdesivir, an investigational broad-spectrum inhibitor of viral replication, is effective in a nonhuman primate model of MERS-CoV infection. This study supports the further development of remdesivir as a potential treatment for MERS-CoV infection. It may also be considered for a wider range of coronaviruses, including the currently emerging novel coronavirus 2019-nCoV.

The provision of nutrients to specific symbiotic microbes is a widespread strategy used by animals to maintain the health of their tissues. However, the mechanisms by which this is achieved are not well understood. Here, we show that the provision of a single glycan, chitin, is sufficient to maintain the health of a symbiont in a mutualism. We also show that the glycan is provided and metabolized only at night, when the animal is active and the symbiont is producing light. This glycan-induced modulation of the symbiont’s habitat may be a general mechanism used by animals to regulate the activities of their associated microbes. (Show more)

This study shows that it is possible to reduce suspension rates in middle schools. The results suggest that the quality of teacher–student relationships is a key factor in reducing suspension rates. This study also shows that it is possible to change teachers’ mindsets about discipline. This is a scalable intervention that can be implemented in schools around the world.

DNA alkylation is a major source of DNA damage that can lead to mutagenesis and cancer. However, the molecular mechanisms of DNA alkylation-induced transcriptional stalling and mutagenesis remain unknown. In this study, we systematically investigated how RNA polymerase II (pol II) recognizes and bypasses regioisomeric O2-, N3-, and O4-ethylthymidine (O2-, N3-, and O4-EtdT) lesions. We found that pol II stalling at O2-EtdT and N3-EtdT sites is exacerbated by TFIIS-stimulated proofreading activity. Assessment for the impact of the EtdT lesions on individual fidelity checkpoints provided mechanistic insights, where the transcriptional lesion bypass routes for the three EtdT lesions are controlled by distinct fidelity checkpoints. The error-free transcriptional lesion bypass route is strongly favored for the minor-groove O2-EtdT lesion. In contrast, a dominant error-prone route stemming from GMP misincorporation was observed for the major-groove O4-EtdT lesion. Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a severe pathogen that causes severe pneumonia in humans. To understand the pathogenesis of MERS-CoV, we engineered MERS viruses with mutations that blocked sequential proteolysis of the virus spike (S) glycoproteins. We found that these mutations compromised MERS-CoV infection into human lung-derived cells, but had little effect on infection into other cell types. These findings suggest that sequential proteolysis is a determinant of MERS-CoV tropism, and may be a target for antiviral therapy.

This study provides robust evidence that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in a cafeteria can increase the proportion of diners choosing vegetarian meals. This has the potential to make a significant contribution to the sustainability of the food system. The study also provides evidence that nudging can be used to increase the proportion of diners choosing vegetarian meals, and that this can be done without having a negative impact on overall sales. This has important implications for the food service sector and for the wider field of nudging.

Cancer is a disease of the cell surface, and the surfaceome is the interface for the cell to interact with the extracellular space. Here we apply a method for the quantitative proteomics of N-linked glycoproteins to reveal how the surfaceome is remodeled in cancer cells expressing oncogenes. We find that each oncogene has a different surfaceome, but the functions of these proteins are harmonized by common biological themes including up-regulation of nutrient transporters, down-regulation of adhesion molecules and tumor suppressing phosphatases, and alteration in immune modulators. These studies provide a broad systems-level view of how specific driver oncogenes remodel the surfaceome and the glycoproteome in a cell autologous fashion, and suggest possible surface targets, and combinations thereof, for drug and biomarker discovery. This work is a significant step forward in understanding the cell surface proteome in cancer. It also provides a platform for the discovery of new surface targets for cancer therapy. (Show more)

The COVID-19 pandemic has led to a surge in interest in vote-by-mail programs. However, there is a lack of evidence on the effects of vote-by-mail on electoral outcomes. In this paper, we provide a comprehensive design-based analysis of the effects of vote-by-mail on electoral outcomes. We find that vote-by-mail does not appear to affect either party’s share of turnout, does not appear to increase either party’s vote share, and modestly increases overall average turnout rates. All three conclusions support the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media. Our findings suggest that vote-by-mail is a safe and effective way to conduct elections during the pandemic.

The SARS-CoV-2 pandemic has had a devastating impact on the global community. The virus has spread rapidly, and the molecular basis for its spread and severity is largely unknown. Here, we report the crystal structure of SARS-CoV-2 ORF8, which is a rapidly evolving accessory protein. The structure reveals a unique dimerization interface that is specific to SARS-CoV-2. This dimerization interface is likely important for the unique immune suppression and evasion activities of ORF8. These activities may contribute to the rapid spread of the virus and the severity of the disease it causes. This work provides insight into the molecular basis of the COVID-19 pandemic. (Show more)

Hypoxia is a common environmental stressor that can cause cerebral edema. However, the underlying mechanisms are not fully understood. Here we show that hypobaric hypoxia induces cerebral edema in rats and neuronal apoptosis in cultured cortical neurons. We also show that the induction of cerebral edema is associated with the up-regulation of the corticotrophin releasing factor (CRF) system, the CRF receptor type 1 (CRFR1), aquaporin-4 (AQP4), and endothelin-1 (ET-1) in the cortex. Furthermore, we show that the up-regulation of CRFR1 and AQP4 is mediated by CRF, which acts on CRFR1 to trigger signaling of cAMP/PKA in cortical astrocytes, leading to activation of AQP4 and cerebral edema. These findings provide insights into the mechanisms of hypoxic cerebral edema and may lead to the development of new therapies for this disease. (Show more)

The development of vascular ECs is a critical step in the formation of vascular networks. However, the development of vascular ECs has been difficult to achieve. Here, we report the development of vascular ECs from human fibroblasts by the induction of ETV2. This study provides a new approach for the development of vascular ECs and may be used for the treatment of vascular disorders. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The discovery of ALKAL1 and ALKAL2 (also named “augmentor-β” and “augmentor-α” or “FAM150A” and “FAM150B,” respectively) as ligands of the receptor tyrosine kinases anaplastic lymphoma kinase (Alk) and leucocyte tyrosine kinase (Ltk) has opened up a new field of research. In this study, we show that these ligands play an important role in zebrafish pigment development. We also demonstrate that the augmentor ligands are essential for embryonic iridophore development and adult body coloration. Importantly, these processes are entirely mediated by Ltk and not by Alk. These experiments establish a physiological link between augmentor ligands and Ltk and demonstrate that particular augmentors activate Ltk in a tissue-specific context to induce iridophore differentiation from neural crest-derived cells and pigment progenitor cells. This work provides a new perspective on the role of ligand-activated RTKs in the development of the vertebrate eye and skin. This study also provides a model system for the study of ligand-activated RTKs in the context of human disease.

Type 2 diabetes (T2D) is a major public health problem. Although the molecular bases of T2D are well known, the treatment of T2D is still limited. In this study, we found that STING, a key molecule in the innate immune system, is required for the function of β-cells. Our study provides a new perspective for the treatment of T2D.

Influenza A viruses are the leading cause of human influenza. They are divided into two groups, the human and avian influenza viruses, which are genetically distinct. The avian influenza viruses are divided into two subtypes, the highly pathogenic and the low pathogenic. The low pathogenic viruses are the main cause of annual epidemics, while the highly pathogenic viruses are the main cause of pandemics. The genome of influenza A viruses is divided into eight segments, which are packaged into viral particles. The packaging of the viral genome is a complex process, which is still not fully understood. Here, we identified a direct interaction between two viral RNA segments, which is required for the packaging of the viral genome. This interaction is sequence specific and favors the copackaging of the interacting RNA segments. Our results provide insights into the molecular details of the packaging process. (Show more)

Atherosclerosis is the leading cause of death worldwide. The development of atherosclerotic lesions is a complex process that involves a series of events, including the induction of proatherosclerotic phenotypes in vascular cells. In this study, we identified a critical role of Yes-associated protein (YAP)/transcriptional coactivator with PDZ-binding motif (TAZ) in the flow regulation of vascular cells. We found that disturbed flow, a common feature of atherosclerosis, activates YAP/TAZ in vascular cells. YAP/TAZ then up-regulates the expression of genes that promote the development of atheroprone phenotypes. Wildfires are a natural part of the ecosystem, but they can also be a threat to human life and property. In the United States, the economic and ecological costs of wildfire have risen substantially in recent decades. Although climate change has likely enabled a portion of the increase in wildfire activity, the direct role of people in increasing wildfire activity has been largely overlooked. We show that humans have vastly expanded the spatial and seasonal “fire niche” in the United States, accounting for 84% of all wildfires and 44% of total area burned. Human-caused wildfires disproportionally occurred where fuel moisture was higher than lightning-started fires, thereby helping expand the geographic and seasonal niche of wildfire. Actions to raise awareness and increase management in regions prone to human-started wildfires should be a focus of United States policy to reduce fire risk and associated hazards. (Abridged)

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods with economic and demographic data and find that three factors predict neighborhood improvement. First, neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements. Second, neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements. Third, neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our method can be used to study the physical dynamics of cities in the future.

Natural repellents are a sustainable and ecofriendly alternative to synthetic pesticides. However, the molecular targets of these repellents in arthropods remain to be elucidated. Here, we identified a scorpion TRP channel as a receptor of natural repellents, which is absent in insects. This study provides a molecular target of natural repellents in arthropods, and may help the rational design of insect control strategy and in conserving biodiversity. It should also help the understanding of the evolution of arthropod–plant interaction. (Show more)

The recent outbreak of Zika virus (ZIKV) has been associated with neurological complications and fetal abnormalities. The mechanisms of disease are not fully understood, but the dynamics of the virus within the host are likely important. Here we present a mathematical analysis of the within-host dynamics of ZIKV in a nonhuman primate model. We show that the virus can be cleared from the host, but that the rate of clearance is highly variable. We also show that an antiviral treatment can reduce the time to undetectable plasma viral load, but that the treatment must be given early in the course of infection to be effective. Finally, we show that the timing of treatment is important for the efficacy of a polymerase inhibitor, favipiravir, and that the timing of treatment is less important for an inhibitor of the viral polymerase, ribavirin. These results can help guide the development of antiviral therapies for ZIKV infection. (Show more)

Coral reefs are among the most valuable ecosystems on Earth, providing food, livelihoods, and recreation to millions of people worldwide. However, they are under threat from a variety of human activities. One of the most severe threats is the ongoing bleaching event, which is driven by climate change. We show that the breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis is driven by altered nutrient cycling, which is a consequence of the increased metabolic energy demand of the coral host. Our findings provide insights into the stability of the coral holobiont and may help us to understand the environmental drivers of bleaching.

The intestinal epithelium is a barrier to the environment and a hub for communication between the host and the microbiome. In this study, we show that the loss of BMP signaling in the epithelium leads to the development of intestinal tumors, which in turn trigger a regenerative response in the microbiome. We identify a JNK-dependent feedback amplification loop between intestinal tumors and the microbiome. We also highlight the importance of controlling the activity level of JNK signaling to maintain epithelial barrier function and host–microbe homeostasis. Our work provides insights into the role of the microbiome in tumorigenesis and the importance of controlling the activity of JNK signaling to maintain epithelial barrier function and host–microbe homeostasis. These findings may lead to the development of new strategies for cancer treatment. (Show more)

Chemotherapy is the most common treatment for breast cancer, but it is often ineffective in patients with advanced disease. In this study, we show that the expression of the ROR1 receptor is up-regulated in breast cancer cells following treatment with chemotherapy. We also show that ROR1 expression is associated with the expression of genes that are induced by the activation of Rho-GTPases, Hippo-YAP/TAZ, or B lymphoma Mo-MLV insertion region 1 homolog (BMI1). Finally, we show that ROR1 expression is associated with the ability of breast cancer cells to metastasize and reengraft Rag2−/−γc−/− mice. These results suggest that targeting ROR1 may improve the response to chemotherapy of patients with breast cancer. (Show more)

The start of deglaciation in the Southern Hemisphere is a key event in the history of the climate system, but the cause of the change is still debated. Here we show that the start of deglaciation was linked to a volcanic eruption, which led to stratospheric ozone depletion and a change in the Southern Hemisphere climate system.

Freshwater fisheries are a critical source of food, recreation, and commerce for hundreds of millions of people around the world. However, they are often overlooked in assessments of global biodiversity and ecosystem services. We provide a global map of riverine fisheries, which reveals that 90% of global catch comes from river basins with above-average stress levels. We also find that freshwater fisheries provide the equivalent of all dietary animal protein for 158 million people, and that poor and undernourished populations are particularly reliant on inland fisheries compared with marine or aquaculture sources. Our analysis highlights the high stakes for improving fishery management, which is critical to both food security and biodiversity conservation. Our enhanced spatial data on estimated catches can facilitate the inclusion of inland fisheries in environmental planning to protect both food security and species diversity. (Abridged)

The development of inherently safe energy devices is a key challenge, and aqueous Li-ion batteries are considered as a promising solution for this purpose. However, the narrow electrochemical stable potential window of aqueous electrolytes limits the energy density and the selection of negative electrode materials. Herein, a type of a negative electrode material is proposed for high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries. The material delivers a large capacity of ∼170 mA ⋅ h ⋅ g−1 with a low operating potential range of 1.9 to 2.8 versus Li/Li+ in 21 m lithium bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl)amide (LiTFSA) aqueous electrolyte. The ability to regenerate after injury is a defining feature of the nervous system. In the adult mammalian CNS, however, neurons are unable to regenerate after injury. Here, we identify a form of regeneration that is remarkably independent of the canonical signaling pathways that mediate regeneration in Caenorhabditis elegans, Drosophila, and mammals. This form of regeneration is triggered by physical lesion of the neuron’s sensory dendrite, and it is enhanced by disrupting activity-dependent calcium signaling. These findings suggest that this form of regeneration may be a powerful platform for the discovery of new genes involved in neuronal regeneration. Moreover, they suggest that the mammalian CNS may be more plastic than previously thought, and that the adult mammalian nervous system may be more regenerative than previously thought.

Recombination is a key process in the generation of genetic diversity and the maintenance of genome integrity. In this study, we describe the distribution of recombination across the genome of a flowering plant, Mimulus guttatus. We find that recombination is highly variable across the genome, with some regions showing no evidence of recombination, and others showing intense activity. We also find that recombination is more likely to terminate in exons than in introns, and that recombination initiation is more likely to occur near the start of genes. These results are consistent with the hypothesis that recombination initiation in eukaryotes is a conserved process.

The resting state network (RSN) hypothesis has been proposed to explain the organization of the human brain. However, the RSN has been defined by the analysis of fluctuations in functional MRI signal, which represent only a small fraction of total neuronal activity. Here, we used metabolic PET, which maps nonfluctuating signals related to total activity, to identify and validate reproducible RSN topographies in healthy and disease populations. We found that the dominant RSN was topographically similar to the DMN in healthy subjects. In contrast, in Parkinson’s disease (PD), this RSN was subordinated to an independent disease-related pattern. Network functionality was assessed by quantifying metabolic RSN expression in cerebral blood flow PET scans acquired at rest and during task performance. We found that the dominant RSN was deactivated during rest and activated during task performance in healthy subjects and early PD patients. In contrast, in advanced PD, the subordinate RSNs were activated during task performance. The 5′ cap structure is the most prominent modification of mRNA. However, there are many other modifications that have been found on mRNAs, including the recently discovered 5′ NAD+ cap. The 5′ cap structure is thought to be important for mRNA stability and translation. It is therefore of interest to determine whether the 5′ NAD+ cap has similar effects. We show that the 5′ NAD+ cap is found on subsets of nuclear and mitochondrial encoded mRNAs in yeast.

Metabolic memory is the phenomenon of maintaining the beneficial effects of intensive diabetes therapy for many years after the discontinuation of intensive therapy. We show that epigenetic DNA methylation alterations at specific loci in blood cells persist for several years after the discontinuation of intensive therapy, and that these loci are associated with glycemia. These results support an epigenetic explanation for metabolic memory.

Triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) is the most aggressive subtype of breast cancer. In this study, we identified a role of fibrous sheath interacting protein 1 (FSIP1) in the sensitivity to chemotherapy drugs in TNBC. FSIP1 deficiency promotes autophagy, which in turn, enhances AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK) signaling and decreases the activity of the mTOR and Wnt/β-catenin pathways. Our findings uncover a role of FSIP1 as well as mechanisms underlying FSIP1 action in drug sensitivity and may, therefore, aid in design of TNBC therapies. (Show more)

Alcohol dependence is a major public health problem. The present study shows that some, but not all, alcohol-dependent subjects develop gut leakiness, which is associated with depression, anxiety, and alcohol craving. Moreover, the composition and activity of the gut microbiota are altered in alcohol-dependent subjects. These results suggest that the gut microbiota is involved in the development of gut barrier and behavioral disorders, which may be important factors in the development of alcohol dependence. Thus, the gut microbiota seems to be a previously unidentified target in the management of alcohol dependence.

The tomato is a model system for the study of fruit ripening and the production of volatile chemicals. However, the biosynthetic pathways of many of these compounds are not known. Here, we report the identification of a gene essential for the production of all the nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit. We also describe the identification of a flavin-dependent monooxygenase enzyme that catalyzes the biosynthesis of these compounds. This work is a major step forward in understanding the biosynthesis of volatile chemicals in fruit and will be of interest to the research community.

The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a key structure in the hippocampus, which is critical for spatial navigation. It is thought to encode information about the local environment, including the location of objects and the direction of travel. However, the anatomical and functional organization of MEC is poorly understood. Here, we used a portable two-photon microscope to record the activity of neurons in MEC during free-running behavior. We found that grid cells, which are thought to encode the local environment, are anatomically segregated from other cell types. This suggests that the organization of grid cell networks may be distinct from that of other cell types. Our results provide a detailed view of the organization of MEC and may help to elucidate the mechanisms underlying navigation. (Show more)

Flowering is a complex process, which is regulated by a variety of factors. In this study, we show that the FT gene, which is known to be involved in flowering regulation, is not required for flowering of the host plant, but is required for flowering of the parasite. This study illustrates the importance of FTs in interplant communication and the role of flowering in the synchronization of flowering time.

The dopamine systems of the brain powerfully influence movement and motivation. Here, we describe a previously unrecognized system of specialized, striosome–containing neurons that form bouquet-like arborizations in the nigrostriatum. These striosome–dendron bouquets likely represent specialized integrative units within the dopamine-containing nigral system. Given evidence that striosomes receive input from cortical regions related to the control of mood and motivation and that they link functionally to reinforcement and decision-making, the striosome–dendron bouquets could be critical to dopamine-related function in health and disease.

We are social creatures, and we seek connection with others. We have long sought to understand how we know when two people are connected. In this work, we show that the speed with which people respond to each other is a robust signal of connection. This signal is used by people to gauge the connection between themselves and others, and it is used by others to gauge the connection between themselves and others. This signal is so robust that it is used by third-party listeners to gauge the connection between themselves and the people they are listening to. This work provides a new way to understand connection, one that is based on the speed with which people respond to each other. It also provides a new way to measure connection, one that is based on the speed with which people respond to each other. And it provides a new way to understand the role of speed in social life.

The sinoatrial node (SAN) is the natural pacemaker of the heart. It is composed of specialized cardiomyocytes, which are responsible for the generation of the electrical impulse. In this study, we report that stromal interaction molecule 1 (STIM1) is expressed in the SAN and is required for the function of the SAN. We also show that STIM1 regulates the function of the SAN by modulating the activity of the Ca2+ release machinery and the activity of the Na+/Ca2+ exchanger. These findings reveal a previously unknown role for STIM1 in the SAN and provide a molecular mechanism for how STIM1 may be involved in the regulation of heart rate. This study provides insight into the mechanisms that control the function of the SAN. (Show more)

Silicon (Si) is an essential element for plants, but its function in plant physiology has been debated. In this study, we show that Si accumulation in rice plants is beneficial in protecting them against the rice leaffolder. We also show that Si accumulation is enhanced by the jasmonate (JA) signaling pathway. Our results suggest that Si and JA may interact in the rice defense system. This study provides a new perspective on the function of Si in plant defense. (Show more)

The role of tetrahydrobiopterin in lipid metabolism is not well understood. Here we show that tetrahydrobiopterin is essential for the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase, which is involved in the metabolism of ether lipids. We demonstrate that alkylglycerol monooxygenase activity is important for the activation of macrophages and that it is essential for the expression of proinflammatory cytokines. Our results reveal a central role of tetrahydrobiopterin and alkylglycerol monooxygenase in ether lipid metabolism of murine macrophages and reveal that alteration of alkylglycerol monooxygenase activity has a profound impact on the lipidome also beyond the class of ether lipids.

Language is a complex cognitive ability that is unique to humans. It is thought to be supported by a mechanism that maintains information in working memory over short periods of time. Here we propose a mechanism for memory that is based on changes in the excitability of neurons. We show that changes in the strength of synaptic connections are not required for memory. Instead, information is maintained in adaptive conductances that reduce firing rates. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it is suitable for temporal integration within the language domain. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

The delivery of biomolecules to plants is a major challenge in plant biology. Here, we demonstrate that DNA nanostructures can be used to deliver biomolecules across the cell wall of plants. We show that the size, shape, compactness, stiffness, and attachment location of the DNA nanostructures are important design parameters for the delivery of biomolecules to plants. We also show that the endogenous gene silencing pathway depends on the attachment location of the siRNA. Our work establishes the feasibility of biomolecule delivery to plants with DNA nanostructures and both details the design parameters of importance for plant cell internalization and also assesses the impact of DNA nanostructure geometry for gene silencing mechanisms. This work will be useful for the delivery of biomolecules to plants in the future.

The world’s largest freshwater lakes are vulnerable to coastal eutrophication, which can lead to harmful algal blooms and other ecological and economic impacts. We show that the majority of nutrient inputs to these lakes come from small tributaries, which are often overlooked in efforts to reduce nutrient loading. Our findings suggest that small tributaries may be a significant source of nutrients to the nearshore zone, where they can fuel harmful algal blooms and other ecological impacts. Our results also highlight the importance of understanding the sources of nutrients to coastal ecosystems, which can be vastly different from those that drive eutrophication in the main lake. Our findings have implications for the management of coastal ecosystems and the development of nutrient reduction strategies for large water bodies.

We study the dynamics of a chemical network in the presence of a strong external forcing. We find that the system is biased toward states that are far from equilibrium and that exhibit a fine-tuned extremization of the external forcing. We show that this behavior is a consequence of the interplay between the network dynamics and the external forcing.

The history of abrupt climate change is a key component of the Earth system history. Here, we present a study of an abrupt climate change event that occurred during a glacial period. We show that the event was linked to a global warming and a doubling of atmospheric CO2. The event was also accompanied by a significant loss of biodiversity. We show that the event was linked to an increase in nutrient fluxes and thermocline stratification.

The palm oil industry is a major driver of tropical deforestation, and certification is the most common tool used to reduce this impact. However, the impact of certification on deforestation has been unclear. Here, we show that certification is associated with reduced deforestation in Indonesia, the world’s largest producer of palm oil. Certification also reduced the amount of forest remaining in oil palm plantations, but had no causal impact on forest loss in peatlands or active fire detection rates. Our results suggest that certification is a promising tool for reducing deforestation, but broader adoption of certification in forested regions, strict requirements to avoid all peat, and routine monitoring of clearly defined forest cover loss in certified and RSPO member-held plantations appear necessary if the RSPO is to yield conservation and climate benefits from reductions in tropical deforestation. Our results also highlight the importance of certification in the context of other policies and programs, such as the Indonesian moratorium on new concessions. We conclude with recommendations for the future of palm oil sustainability certification.

The exocyst complex is involved in the last steps of exocytosis, which is essential to organisms across kingdoms. In humans, its dysfunction is correlated with several significant diseases, such as diabetes and cancer progression. Investigation of the dynamic regulation of the exocyst-related processes using mutants in genetically tractable organisms such as Arabidopsis thaliana is limited by the lethality or the severity of phenotypes. We discovered that the small molecule Endosidin2 (ES2) binds to the EXO70 (exocyst component of 70 kDa) subunit of the exocyst complex, resulting in inhibition of exocytosis and endosomal recycling in both plant and human cells and enhancement of plant vacuolar trafficking. This study not only provides a valuable tool in studying exocytosis regulation but also offers a potentially new target for drugs aimed at addressing human disease. (Show more)

Sex determination is a key process in the evolution of animal diversity. In many species, sex is determined by a single locus, but in others, sex is determined by multiple interacting loci. In this study, we investigate the effects of multiple interacting sex determination loci in the cichlid fish Metriaclima mbenjii. We find that multiple sex determination alleles interact to produce four possible sex classes: females, males, and two types of hermaphrodites. We also find that the hermaphroditic sex classes are linked by a modular system of sexual polymorphism, where the hermaphroditic sex classes are linked by a modular system of sexual polymorphism. This system of sexual polymorphism provides context for understanding the evolutionary causes and consequences of maintenance, gain, or loss of sex determination alleles in populations. (Show more)

The retina is a highly oxidative tissue, and the photoreceptor cell layer is particularly vulnerable to oxidative damage. The role of iron in this process is not well understood. We show that the levels of iron in the retina, as measured by transferrin receptor mRNA expression, are critical for the levels of reactive oxygen species and the photodegradation of the retinal pigment adduct A2E. These findings have implications for the pathogenesis of age-related macular degeneration, a leading cause of blindness in the elderly. They also suggest that the levels of iron in the retina may be a target for therapeutic intervention. (Show more)

Predators are the main drivers of biodiversity and ecosystem functioning. However, the evolution of predator specialization has been considered an evolutionary dead end. Here we show that the evolution of predator specialization is not only possible, but also common in nature. Our findings contribute to understanding how specialization and morphological evolution have shaped present-day food webs.

The evolution of the human hand is a key area of research in human evolution. This study provides the earliest evidence for the evolution of a key feature of the human hand, the third metacarpal styloid process. Cancer is a metabolic disease, and thus the metabolism of cancer cells is different from that of normal cells. In this study, we show that the enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT) is a metabolic target of cancer, and that it is a potential metabolic vulnerability of cancer. We also show that cancer cells have unique metabolic vulnerabilities, and that these vulnerabilities can be exploited to treat cancer.

Deforestation is a major driver of environmental change, and the loss of natural landscapes is a key contributor to the global food crisis. However, little is known about the role of natural landscapes in improving people’s diets. This study shows that deforestation can reduce people’s access to fruits and vegetables, which are essential for meeting dietary vitamin A requirements. Conversely, forest fragmentation can increase access to these foods, which is important for meeting dietary vitamin A requirements. The results have important implications for policy makers, who should consider the role of natural landscapes in improving people’s diets, particularly in rural areas of low- and middle-income countries.

Mechanization has been a key driver of the Green Revolution, which has increased food production by 200% over the last 60 y. However, the increase in capacity has been accompanied by higher vehicle weights that increase risks of subsoil compaction. We show that while surface contact stresses remained nearly constant over the course of modern mechanization, subsoil stresses have propagated into deeper soil layers and now exceed safe mechanical limits for soil ecological functioning. We developed a global map for delineating subsoil compaction susceptibility based on estimates of mechanization level, mean tractor size, soil texture, and climatic conditions. The alarming trend of chronic subsoil compaction risk over 20% of arable land, with potential loss of productivity, calls for a more stringent design of farm machinery that considers intrinsic subsoil mechanical limits. As the total weight of modern harvesters is now approaching that of the largest animals that walked Earth, the sauropods, a paradox emerges of potential prehistoric subsoil compaction.
